http://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2004-04-29-bush-panel_x.htm
 
 
 
 Bush, Cheney meet with 9/11 panel 
 From staff and wire reports
 WASHINGTON - President Bush and Vice President Cheney met in private Thursday with the commission investigating the Sept. 11, 2001 terror attacks, likely facing questions about whether they neglected to focus on terrorism the attacks and how they will retool intelligence gathering.
 
 My question is, why did two of the commission members find it necessary to leave early? I understand one of them went to meet with another Senator and the other left to meet with a representative of Canada. Does this show their priorities?

Why did Bush insist he and Cheney testify together? Wouldn't you get a more accurate, unrehearsed, unbiased accounting of the events if you questioned the two gentlemen separately? With all the constraints the White House put on the meeting, credibility took a backseat to political protocol.

 I see nothing wrong with their meeting together. Perhaps the White House detected a plan by the obviously biased committee to catch them on some inconsequential discrepency just to claim they gave inconsistent answers to a single question.
 
 I haven't heard the questions or the answers, but I believe the committee was satisfied with the meeting.

That seems like a pretty basic rule of questioning: separate the parties and see if their stories match. My understanding was they wouldn't agree to be sworn under oath, so what good was the meeting??

Neither was Clinton under oath.

 
 I guess I just don't understand the double standard. If a question can't be answered because of "national security", just say, "I can't answer that because of national security......" Otherwise, any questions or comments should be held to the highest standards of truthfulness, so why not put them under oath? We all know it's possible for even a President to lie, you've been good enough to point that out about Clinton. Just swear them in like anyone else and eliminate the impression of any improprieties!

Otherwise, any questions or comments should be held to the highest standards of truthfulness, so why not put them under oath? We all know it's possible for even a President to lie, you've been good enough to point that out about Clinton. Just swear them in like anyone else and eliminate the impression of any improprieties!

 
 It's a political cat-and-mouse game on both sides. Once a person is under oath, the inquisitor can ask any question whatsoever, including something as insignificant as, "What's your favorite TV show?"
 
 I suppose a compromise that may have led to their willingness to testify under oath might be an agreement that they have  all  of the questions in writing before the meeting. Otherwise, they would open themselves to the expected vicious attacks of their political opponents.
 
 I think it would have been more enlightening to the public to have the questions and answers in writing...but you shouldn't expect sensible fair play from either side of Washington. They don't trust each other enough for that to happen.
